Hi Carol.  
  
Yes, while the EA is being tested and tweaked I am continuing to paper trade this strategy. If both the 'manual' and EA trades are with the same broker the results should be identical.  
I don't give a lot of credence to backtesting mainly because of the lack of facilities available to accurately do so.... so I couldn't advise you on historical results. I think Pr1mer is wanting to do some kind of historical testing using an excel spreadsheet....he's hoping for help from bullrock in this regard. His logic (which is very sound) is that various pairs will perform better than others over different timeframes and visa versa. Therefore testing over a short period may not necessarily give an accurate analysis of which pairs perform better than others with this strategy.  
Despite this, I am still basing my evaluation of this strategy mostly on forward tested results until I'm convinced otherwise. Having said that, the use of the EA will make it easier to trade multiple pairs without the hassle of having to manually place so many orders, thus eliminating the need of a shortlist in the hope of selecting only the best performing pairs.

By SA i assume you mean South Africa. Try downloading a demo version of Metatrader 4 from Alpari or Interbankfx, both give you real time data as part of the demo. In this software if you use the 1D timeframe you should be getting the high and low for each day.  
  
You can lose a maximum of 180 points per pair per day. I think Mikelath is trading 3 pairs so his max loss is 540 points.  
  
I've seen Mikelath's testing results and they look impressive but I am concerned that the risk ratio is not high enough and over time when the cluster of losses come the strategy will struggle. BUT that is something that only backtesting and forward testing can prove.

> 
> Hi all and welcome to the DAILY95PIPS strategy.  
>    
>  Before we start I urge you to paper trade any new strategy including this one before committing any of your own funds.  
>    
>  Also bear in mind that this system is by no means new and may look familiar to some of you. I am simply passing it on from my predecessors/mentors in the hope that it adds to your existing trading arsenal and increases your trading results.  
>    
>  The basis of this system is VERY simple and has proven to be profitable, though I am adjusting the money management/profit targets. So results for this revised version will be realised on this thread. I must also emphasise the well known phrase that "past performance is no guarantee of future returns".  
>    
>  I will add the daily trading results to this thread as we go along. See post#598 for updated results for the current week. Weekly and individual pairs results are at post #591. (Please disregard the next post #2 as I am unable to add to it.)  
>    
>  That being said, let us proceed with the strategy.  
>    
>  OVERVIEW:  
>  This is a pure "set and forget" system where trades are placed at the same time everyday. The option is also there for those inclined to monitor their positions to adjust stop levels as profit targets are reached.  
>  By setting multiple profit targets we are exercising money management, while aiming for 95pips profit from a 50pip move in price.  
>  We will simply be placing orders 5pips above the previous days HIGH and 5pips below the previous days LOW.  
>  Use a 30pip stop loss for all orders.  
>  Orders are placed on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.  
>    
>  EXECUTION:  
>    
>  1.) At 5pm EST open the 1hr chart (2hrs b4 start of the Asian session) of USDJPY. ( In an attempt to pre-empt questions about how this strategy works on other pairs, I will post results comparing GBPUSD, GBPJPY, EURJPY, and EURUSD. You're welcome to add to the list.)  
>  For those whose brokers spreads are still wide at 5pm EST on Sunday (which is 7am my time on a Monday here in Brisbane), in order to avoid the wide spreads you may need to wait until they reduce to normal before placing the orders for the day. I typically have to wait until around 8pm EST.  
>    
>  2.) Use the high and low of the previous 17hrs. For Mondays orders go back as far as 00:00 EST on Friday for high and low.  
>    
>  3.) Open a total of 6 PENDING orders (for each pair) including 3 BUY STOPS and 3 SELL STOPS that expire within 24hrs (I use 18hrs) as follows:  
>    
>  Buy/Long Orders:  
>  i. #1 - Entry = HIGH+5pips, Take Profit=15pips, S/L=30pips  
>  ii. #2 - Entry = HIGH+5pips, Take Profit=30pips, S/L=30pips  
>  iii. #3 - Entry = HIGH+5pips, Take Profit=50pips, S/L=30pips  
>    
>  Sell/Short Orders:  
>  i. #1 - Entry = LOW-5pips, Take Profit=15pips, S/L=30pips  
>  ii. #2 - Entry = LOW-5pips, Take Profit=30pips, S/L=30pips  
>  iii. #3 - Entry = LOW-5pips, Take Profit=50pips, S/L=30pips  
>    
>  That's it.  
>    
>  Once you have placed your orders you are free to go and do something else with your day as this strategy does not require you to be monitoring the trades. Though, as already mentioned, to maximise results you may choose to adjust stop levels when profit targets are reached.  
>    
>  There can be 4 possible outcomes after either the long or short trades are triggered:  
>  1.) All 3 profit targets are reached for a total of +95pips.  
>  2.) The first 2 profit targets are reached (+45pips) and the remaining lot is stopped out (-30pips) leaving a total of +15pips.  
>  3.) The first profit target is reached (+15pips) and the two remaining lots are stopped out for a total of -45pips.  
>  4.) All 3 lots are stopped out for a total of -90pips.  
>  Additional to this is the variable outcomes of when both the long and short trades are triggered.  
>  Also note that for those so inclined to monitor the trades, stop levels may be adjusted on remaining lot/s to protect already achieved profits. Trailing stops may also be used at your discretion.  
>    
>  Please note that as a general rule of thumb you should not risk any more than 3% of your trading account on any one trade.  
>  Therefore, with the DAILY95PIPS strategy the order size will need to be divided between the long and short orders. The total potential loss on the long orders (90pips) will therefore add up to 3% of your trading account.  
>  Alternatively, you could risk 3% of your trading capital on EACH order, totalling 9% of your trading capital being risked for the long trades. The same applies to the short orders.  
>    
>  Happy trading everyone !
>

I just came across this thread and I was amazed to see that the system espoused is VERY similar to one I use.  
  
I trade 4 pairs: GBP/USD, USD/CAD, EUR/AUD, GBP/JPY. I chose these pairs because for the most part they are non-correlated.  
  
I enter 2 trades on each pair:  
\- Long on daily high + 5 pips (10 pips for GBP/JPY)  
\- Short on daily high - 5 pips (10 pips for GBP/JPY)  
  
I have a SL of the 33% of the 22-day ATR  
and a TP of 66% of the 22-day ATR.  
  
For GBP/USD that means that I have a SL of about 50 pips and a TP of about 100 pips. And for GBP/JPY I have a SL of about 90 pips and a TP of about 180 pips.  
  
When the market is trending I make out like a bandit, however when the market is ranging (like is was for the 1st 2 weeks of October) I get killed.  
  
I'm currently working on trying to incorporate daily ADX to determine when the market is trending or ranging. I'm thinking that I'll only enter trades when ADX is above 25 and sloping up. I'll stay out if ADX is sloping down. I haven't tried this yet, but I'll start next week. Hopefully it will help me stay out of the market when I know my strategy doesn't work.  
  
I'm also trying to come up with a way where I can take partial profits (like the OP does) along the way; but I want to keep my 2:1 win:loss ratio and I don't want to have my SL too close. I like to give the market a little "breathing room".  
  
Anyway, I couldn't help putting in my $0.02 because my strategy is so close to the OPs.

**Daystarthour** \- hour in your timezone/used by your broker when the forex day starts = when you want your stop orders placed.  
**Lookbackhours** \- how many hours to look back when calculating day high / low  
**OrderExpirationHours** \- after how many hours do stop orders expire.  
  
Pr1mer

To **armrd08** :  
EA moves SL to B/E after reaching first TP. That's the original idea suggested by Mike. In next version I can add a setting when (if at all) to move to B/E point.  
  
To **cashfinder** :  
I'm glad some took a look into the EA source ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
Your solution is nice but not convenient for everyone. I have already fixed multiple pairs problem by simplifying EA by just adding Magic Number setting. It'll be available soon.  
  
To **mikelath** :  
I'll just add a new setting to next version of EA to turn on/off trailing stop (with adjustable number of pips) to the last order. Than we'll be able to test whether it's better.  
  
Cheers,  
Pr1mer ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)

Hi,  
New version of EA is ready.  
I have finally fixed problem with using EA for multiple pairs.  
Additionally, I have added trailing stop feature and possibility to adjust break-even move.  
  
Below I'll describe new settings, for others look for description in post #541 ([http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost...&postcount=541](http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost.php?p=1633321&postcount=541)).  
  
**UpdateToBE** \- number of pips in profit, when stoploss is moved to break-even point, e.g. when set to 15 - stop loss will be moved to opening price after reaching 15 pips profit. If you want to move SL to b/e when first take profit is taken, set to the same value as **TakeProfit1** setting. The same goes for TP2, TP3.  
  
**UseTrailingStopOnLastOrder** , **TrailingStop** \- these are tricky ones ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)  
When **UseTrailingStopOnLastOrder** is set to _false_ , there will simply be no trailing stop for last order ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1) So take profit will be taken at the value of **TakeProfit3**. **TrailingStop** setting value is insignifficant in this case.  
When **UseTrailingStopOnLastOrder** is set to _true_ , trailing stop will be activated when order reached **TakeProfit3** pips value. Trailing stop value is then equal to **TrailingStop** setting value.  
_Example_ :  
We have **TakeProfit3** =50, **UseTrailingStopOnLastOrder** =_true_ , **TrailingStop** =20.  
Let's assume that buy orders were opened at the price of 1.2350. At the level of 1.2400 we'll have 50 pips of profit (for simplicity of this example spread is not taken into account). From now on, whenever price goes up, stop loss for last order will be moved to 20 pips below actual price. For example, let's take such sequence:  
1) price - 1.2400, sl - 1.2380  
2) price - 1.2405, sl - 1.2385  
3) price - 1.2402, sl - 1.2385  
4) price - 1.2407, sl - 1.2387  
5) price - 1.2405, sl - 1.2387  
etc.  
  
**EAMagicNumber** \- for advanced users only. It is a random number generated for this EA. Change is when using other EAs for the same account and they happen to use the same magic number (very unprobable). There's no need to change this value for different pairs - EA attached to a chart will only manage orders with magic number equal to EAMagicNumber setting and symbol correstponding to this chart.

> Hi,

>    
>  Below I'll describe new settings, for others look for description in post #541 ([http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost...&postcount=541](http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost.php?p=1633321&postcount=541)).  
>    
>  **UpdateToBE** \- number of pips in profit, when stoploss is moved to break-even point, e.g. when set to 15 - stop loss will be moved to opening price after reaching 15 pips profit. If you want to move SL to b/e when first take profit is taken, set to the same value as **TakeProfit1** setting. The same goes for TP2, TP3.  
>    
>  **UseTrailingStopOnLastOrder** , **TrailingStop** \- these are tricky ones ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)  
>  When **UseTrailingStopOnLastOrder** is set to _false_ , there will simply be no trailing stop for last order ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1) So take profit will be taken at the value of **TakeProfit3**. **TrailingStop** setting value is insignifficant in this case.  
>  When **UseTrailingStopOnLastOrder** is set to _true_ , trailing stop will be activated when order reached **TakeProfit3** pips value. Trailing stop value is then equal to **TrailingStop** setting value.  
>  _Example_ :  
>  We have **TakeProfit3** =50, **UseTrailingStopOnLastOrder** =_true_ , **TrailingStop** =20.  
>  Let's assume that buy orders were opened at the price of 1.2350. At the level of 1.2400 we'll have 50 pips of profit (for simplicity of this example spread is not taken into account). From now on, whenever price goes up, stop loss for last order will be moved to 20 pips below actual price. For example, let's take such sequence:  
>  1) price - 1.2400, sl - 1.2380  
>  2) price - 1.2405, sl - 1.2385  
>  3) price - 1.2402, sl - 1.2385  
>  4) price - 1.2407, sl - 1.2387  
>  5) price - 1.2405, sl - 1.2387  
>  etc.  
>    
>  **EAMagicNumber** \- for advanced users only. It is a random number generated for this EA. First I would like to say that this is a great thread. It has taken me a couple of days to digest all of the information and come to grips with the logic of this system. I would also like to say that Pr1mer is one of the best programmers I have ever met in one of these forums.  
  
Having said that I would like to offer the following. I only use IBFX for my demo trading and have had a lot of experience with them.  
  
If you are using IBFX you will need to set your **DayStartHour** to **21.** The IBFX demo server is currently on EST+4 hours.  
  
The second problem with IBFX is that they do not start their trading day on Sunday until 18:00 EST. Using the Expert for this system will not generate any trades for the Sunday/Monday session since it is set to put in the orders at 17:00EST. I have made a change to the expert to take this into account.   
  
Also, when using IBFX, you will only look back 16 bars for the Sunday/Monday session buystop and sellstop orders since there is an hour missing with their 16:00 EST close on Friday and their 18:00 EST open on Sunday.  
I have altered the expert to take this into account as well.  
  
Please be advised that the expert that I have attached is the .04 current version of Pr1mer's expert with changes that only work with IBFX. It must be attached to your chart and active Sunday @ 18:00 EST - 18:59 EST to get the first days trades set.  
  
I would like to close by saying that if Pr1mer does not want anyone altering his/her programming, please let me know and I will not post any changes again. His/her programming knowledge is far superior to mine and I would not want to offend him/her in any way.  
  
I hope that my input is helpful.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)

Backtesting in MT4 for this system will not work for a few different reasons:  
  
1) The time changes that go on during the year will change the calculations.  
  
2) The only way to truely backtest a system in MT4 is to import tick data and use it on a 1M chart. In order to do this the EA would need to be rewritten to account for using a 1M chart. The tick modeling that is used by MT4 on the 1 hour charts that you get is from 1M data and the program basically guesses how the ticks went within the 1H bar and 1M bar based on the smaller time frames. The key to this is that MT4 **GUESSES/MODELS** the ticks. This is why the backtester is not trustworthy the way it is currently used by most people.  
  
Hope this helps! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)

Thanks for links giraia.  
  
Hmmm...yes, the strategy is similar in that the setup is the same (5pips above and below the high and low) however the stops and profit targets are different, and multiple profit targets are not used by hans123. D95P moves stops to BE after the 1st PT has been reached, thus locking in partial profits...hans123 system moves stops to BE after price has moved somewhat (according to the pair) however it's still possible that the trades will stopout without ANY profits. Both strategies have the potential of stopping out for a loss....  
  
Regarding:  
If a certain position is taken and price turns against you and it breaks the other side of the breakout channel then turn. If the breakout channel is broader then the stoploss first the stoploss will be hit. If the breakout channel is narrower then the stoploss then hitting the other side means that you have to turn your position. There is only one turn per time frame possible. This rule is a result of all previous rules. You can skip this rule if you want.  
  
I'd definitely be inclined to skip this rule and would not be surprised if this was the cause of the large drawdown. I don't see the point in trying to 'chase' price. If price movement triggers the orders and reaches profit targets that's very good...if it doesn't I'm happy to move on and wait for the next day.  
  
Another consideration that comes to mind is the pairs chosen. One of the objectives with the D95P thread is to shortlist the best performing pairs with the parameters of this strategy. Surprisingly, of the 2 pairs suggested for hans123 GBPUSD hasn't made the D95P shortlist....however EURUSD has.  
  
At the end of the day I see the only mildly accurate similarity being the initial setup ( 5pips above and below the high and low).   
  
That being said, any mechanical system is always subject to performing better of worse depending on market conditions and I thank you for bringing this to my attention. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)

I am going to state this again just so everyone gets the same clear picture:  
  
**YOU CANNOT BACK TEST THIS SYSTEM WITH THIS EXPERT!!!**  
  
If you run this expert in the backtester on a 1M chart it will only look back 17 minutes before it is suppose to place the orders! This is why it will not work. No matter what chart you run this expert on it will only look back 17 periods (or in other words, bars) prior to placing the pending orders for the day. If you run it on a 1H chart the tick modeling is not accurate, no matter what the modeling quality is. So please do yourself a favor and stop trying.  
  
In regards to the period converter for MT4, it is designed to make larger period bars from smaller period ones. Example, 1H bars from 30M or 30M from 1M.  
  
Over the weekend I will try to make some adjustments to the expert and make one for testing purposes only.  
  
Hope This Helps!![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)

Giraia_br,  
  
Yes I am using the expert exactly the way that I posted it with the exception of using fixed lots. You can change the **FixedLots** from 0.0 to .10, or what ever you want, to trade in the same lot size all of the time. You can leave the **FixedLots = 0.0** and the expert will automatically risk 1% of your margin account for each trade. You can also change the **Risk** from .01 to a larger or smaller amount. Do not change the **Margin** because this is the setting used to decide how far to move the BS and SS above and below the high and low.  
  
Hope this helps.

When you want to use EA for different pairs just drag the EA on the charts with these pairs. This creates different instances of EA for each pair.  
Each EA manages orders that have corresponding **EAMagicNumber** and current chart's symbol, so you do NOT need to change this setting when using only this EA for different pairs (although you can, like PipHunter196 does).  
This setting is handy when you want to use this EA several times for the same pair or with other EAs (just check if it's not using the same magic - highly unprobable).  
Hope this helps.  
  
Cheers,  
Pr1mer

The reason for this is that you have the trailing stop turned on for the third order. Thus it will not have a take profit since the stop will be your exit.  
  
Turn it off and that should change.

Hello Everyone,  
  
In this post, and the following, you will find the EAs that I have changed to work with the following brokers:  
  
**IBFX (InterbankFx)**  
**Alpari**  
**FXDD**  
**North Finance**  
**ODL**  
  
**These need to be loaded on your platform and activated PRIOR to the start of trading Sunday, or whenever the first 1H bar for your broker is formed for the week. This EA is setup to work on a 1H chart. If you attach it to any other time frame, it will not trade according to the rules set forth by Mikelath.**  
  
  
Each EA has been modified to the time changes for each broker that I have listed above. They also take into account if the broker has missing bars from their close on Friday and their open on Sunday.  
  
Pr1mer wrote this EA and deserves the credit for doing so. I am just trying to help with the time issues and, thus, I have made a couple small programming changes. His instructions on how to set up the other parameters are [HERE](http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost.php?p=1682611&postcount=687).  
  
If we can get everyone on the same time schedule, we can start checking other aspects of this EA. If there are any changes that need to be made after we start using the Fall Versions of the EA I will let you all know.

Maybe you should try to increase the UpdateToBE by another 10 or 20 pips.

Execution in both direction will cancel each other out, except for broker fees (spread), which are two-fold...till one is stopped out first.  
  
Dump the position & wait for another go-round.

Hi fellow pipsters. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44b.png?v=15.1)  
  
Some of you may be wondering why I got +407pips on Friday and you didn't....  
  
After repeated experiences of having the 2nd and 3rd orders being stopped out after the EA moved the SL to BE once the 1st profit target was reached I decided to change the UpdatetoBE setting from 15 to 30, meaning that the EA now moves the stoploss to breakeven only after the 2nd profit target of 30pips is reached.  
This has worked well so far, however be aware that it also exposes the trades to more potential loss ie. once the 15PT is reached and price retraces to the -30SL the result will be -45pips instead of locking +15pips if the SL had been moved to BE after the 1st PT was reached. The upside of course is that the 2nd and 3rd orders now have more room to move in achieving their profits which is what happened on Friday.  
  
I'm also using the trailing stop feature on the 3rd order.  
  
Tweaking of this system continues and I'm still over the moon about Pr1mer creating such a great EA ! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f923.png?v=15.1)

Hi Tim.  
  
I'm not really inclined to do a backtest in order to determine which days of the week have performed better than others, as this average could just as easily change again as further forward testing is done. If you'd like to do this exercise then be my guest as all the daily and weekly results are on this thread to help you with the calculations. Have fun.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f61c.png?v=15.1):  
So far I've found that good results can come on any day, therefore I leave the potential for profits open for the full 5 days, Mon-Fri.  
Regarding the worst possible scenario for the day, well it happened today with EJ, UJ and EU all stopping out for a total loss of -270pips. I think this is the first day it's happened. The worst possible scenario on a longer timeframe would be if this repeated everyday until my trading account is blown.   
So yes, this is also possible though not very likely. The best MM pertaining to this strategy is the use of multiple profit targets, moving the stoploss to BE after the 1st or 2nd PT is reached and using a TS on the 3rd order.  
If you can think of anyway to improve upon this MM system I'm sure we'd all appreciate you sharing it.  
Having said all that, I'll keep praying for success. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/270c-fe0f.png?v=15.1)  
  
cheers

Thanks mikelath for posting this strategy. Thanks primer for the brilliant ea. Thanks all the other contributors for your contributions to this thread. I have read the first 20 pages and last 10, and will catch up on the pages in between now that FF is back on line.  
  
I have already done my first +203, within three-and-a-half hours of the ea setting the first orders. Fantastic. I know there will be losing days, but the results you have all been getting speak for themselves.  
  
This is my 10th month of surviving, just, in Forex. I have made and lost money, mostly lost. I have been learning and gradually become aware of the importance of Fibonacci support and resistance points. I am a looooonnnnnnng way from expertise, so I make this contribution with due deference to more experienced traders.  
  
I used Fib s\r to adjust the EU third order tp. The attached image shows the tp as set by the ea to slightly below -61.8, a major support. There is every chance that a price will rebound from this, so I set my own tp a couple of pips higher. As things turned out, the price broke the barrier so I lost a couple of pips; another day I might have saved myself some profit.  
  
I also checked that the stop losses were not affected. For example, a sl on a sell just below a resistance point could save the trade if moved beyond that point. The negative is that I could lose a few more pips if the price continued rising, but the image is a great example of s\r at work.  
  
After the thick red candle, there is a faint, hard-to-see thin green candle where the price spent an hour bouncing between -23.6 and -50 before finally making up its mind and falling later on. You will need to enlarge the image to see the candle.  
  
I offer these thoughts as a possible refinement for those able to monitor the positions once the ea has opened them. I have attached a great Fib indicator, courtesy of Spud, which shows the s\r points in detail. It is worth changing the colours to white to make it more legible.  
  
Good luck everybody. I am putting the ea on my live account in time for tomorrow, so expect the strategy to begin failing instantly. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f633.png?v=15.1)

I don't have an answer, yet - but it looks like the market filling in the gaps got me anyway. I hope I am not boring you, but let me take a second to explain why this is a problem  
  
When the market closes on Friday and then reopens on Sunday, it often opens at a price different than it closed. This 'gap' can be anywhere from a few to a lot of pips. If the market closed anywhere near the low or high from the previous day, the pending orders would be filled. The problem is that the market tends to reverse and fill in these gaps, often times to just to reverse again and move back the original direction. I even think there is a thread talking about how to trade these gaps  
  
If your settings are as mine, the EA opened and filled orders based on the gaps, then hits the stop loss as the market reverses and fills in the gaps.   
  
When I have some time, I am going to go back and see how often this has been occuring. The only answer I can think of right now is to turn off the EA and skip using it on the first day of the week.  
  
Any other thoughts?  
  
Tim

Exactly. You look for high and low from the midnight to 5pm CET. (5:00pm - 17 = 0:00)  
  
Then :  
BUY pending order: HIGH + 5 pips + spread   
SELL pending order: LOW - 5pips  
  
You have to add spread to your high calculation if you use ask price. If you dont apply the spread to the calculation your buy order will be lower (depends on spread) and executed sooner. If you use the calculator, apply "BID" price or "ASK + spread" price for correct calculation of your buy order.

I should have left those eu trades open on my live account. They triggered on the demo and have made +45 now, with the third order still in place. The ea hasn't closed it; it should be placing my new trades in about 40 minutes, at 8.00 am London time.  
  
I have been thinking about the losing trades - not that I have any yet. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
From what I have learned, accepted wisdom is: 1) trading against the long-term trend is financial suicide; 2) the long-term trend is found by looking two time frames further on in the charts.  
  
I have looked at the daily charts for eu (screaming upwards), uj (up but with a strong retrace) and uj (gone to hell in a handbasket). Mike, or any of the others who have been trading this system for a while, have you any idea how many of your losing trades were taken out in the opposite direction to the prevailing trend?  
  
Fibonacci support and resistance could well be playing a part. For those of you unfamiliar with Fib s&r, it works like this. Suppose a pair is trending upwards like the eu. Eventually, it hits a Fib resistance point that traders regard as an important barrier to further progress, so they close their orders and take their profits. This causes the price to fall until it hits a certain point that traders (often the very ones who closed in the first place) consider will signal a return to the upward momentum; they will then go long again. Fib s&r points thus become self-fulfilling prophesies.  
  
We can play with these points. There is a Fib retracement tool on the MT4 platform; look for the icon with 4 rows of dots and an F in the bottom right corner. Go to, say, the eu chart on any timeframe and look anywhere for a place where the upward movement of the last few weeks is interrupted by a downward movement. Click on the Fib icon, then on the chart at the bottom of the upward movement and drag to the top of it. You will see the Fib retrace points plotted on the chart. If you haven't done this before, you will be interested in the way certain points trigger counter-movement time and time again.  
  
I like trading the 30 min chart for 20-30 pips; Fib 61.8 seems most important here. I love scalping for +5 on the 5 min chart, where Fib 100 is most important; once the price breaks this then making +5 is easy.  
  
I don't know what the crucial point is on our 1H tf, but it will be one of the smaller ones; 38.2 or 23.6 are my guesses, as we are dealing with a longer time frame.  
  
All this could affect _this_ tradingsystem thus: a strong price retrace triggers the pending order; the retrace is at its apex, and so the price reverses back in the direction of the trend. Hey-presto, -90.  
  
All my winning trades have been taken in the direction of the prevailing daily trend apart from the uj yesterday. Do a retrace thing on the daily, dragging from top to bottom of the previous downward movement, and you will see a retrace almost to the 38.2. I might simply have been lucky yesterday.  
  
All of which is a long-winded way of suggesting that we cancel (ea) or do not set manually, the pending orders that are in the opposite direction to the trend as seen on the Daily chart. What do you guys think?

Steve  
  
I for one am very pragmatic - if it ain't broke - don't fix it.   
  
In stating the obvious, it is the trend reversals that cost pips using this system. If having the EA initiate the pending orders at the opening of London means fewer revesals during the day, then the losses should also be fewer.  
  
Does the EA still close all orders at the end of the trading day before the Far East markets open? If so, one of the downsides I see is that the orders would have less time to do their thing. It will be interesting to see what effect different 'start' times will have on the results. Even more curious, will each pair have a 'best' time for the EA to initiate the pending the orders? For example, maybe EURUSD works best when the orders are started at the open of London where USDJPY may work best when the orders are started at the open of New York.   
  
The potential is endless - but the possibilities may my head hurt...  
  
Any more thoughts....  
  
Tim

Ye Gods, anybody got any headache pills?  
  
This thread started with a fire-and-forget strategy. Here we are trying to turn it into a fire-and-make-even-better strategy. Life isn't easy, is it?  
  
Ok, my demo account has sent the pending orders at 22.00 gmt (5.00 pm est). My live account is set to do the same 10 hours later, at 8.00 am gmt (3.00 am est). It will be interesting to see what happens to the two sets of orders. Guess which I hope is right? ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
My best guess? Just as a trend is a trend or a blip depending on the time frame involved, so a breakout happens from whatever starting point is chosen or it doesn't. A breakout just prior to setting the pending orders automatically creates a fresh channel to set the orders by.  
  
So, if the breakout is in the direction of the prevailing trend, then it is more likely to be a genuine breakout. If not, it is more likely to be a brief retrace. I am thinking about aloud here, and it is proving most useful. This encourages me to check the direction of the trend when looking at the orders the ea has set.  
  
Hmmmmmmm. Simple, this forex business isn't it? The price goes up, so we buy and make a fortune. It falls, so we sell and make a fortune. If only.........

Hi all and thanks for the great thread...  
  
I recently found this and decided to try and help with some demo testing. My setup is as follows:  
  
11 IBFX demo accounts with the appropriate EA  
Running on all 19 currency pairs offered by IBFX and 1 hour charts  
50k demo accounts trading 1 fixed mini lot  
  
  
Since times have come up a bit I decided to make 11 accounts to try different start times and look back hours as follows:

  1. **Demo #01) Start 22EST / Look back 17**

    1. **Original strategy**

  2. **Demo #02) Start 00GMT / Look back 23**

    1. Tokyo open back 23hrs (almost a full day)

  3. **Demo #03) Start 08GMT / Look back 23**

    1. London open back 23hrs (almost a full day)

  4. **Demo #04) Start 13GMT / Look back 23**

    1. New York open back 23hrs (almost a full day)

  5. **Demo #05) Start 22GMT / Look back 23**

    1. Sydney open back 23hrs (almost a full day)

  6. **Demo #06) Start 00GMT / Look back 02**

    1. Tokyo open back to Sydney open

  7. **Demo #07) Start 08GMT / Look back 08**

    1. London open back to Tokyo open (00GMT)

  8. **Demo #08) Start 13GMT / Look back 05**

    1. New York open back to London open

  9. **Demo #09) Start 22GMT / Look back 09**

    1. Sydney open back to New York open

  10. **Demo #10) Start 13GMT / Look back 13**

    1. New York open back to Tokyo open (00GMT)

  11. **Demo #11) Start 22GMT / Look back 22**

    1. Sydney open back to Tokyo open (00GMT)

The idea would be to run the demos and try to take out pairs that never do well and maybe find out how pairs do during different start times and based off of different look back hours. Any thoughts?

  * Nov 17, 2007 5:32am  Nov 17, 2007 5:32am 

  * [![](https://assets.faireconomy.media/nfs/customavatars/thumbs/medium/avatar53951_5.gif) mtaboneweb](mtaboneweb)

  * | Joined Nov 2007  | Status: Commercial Member | [694 Posts](/search?do=process&provider=Member&searchuser=53951)

Thanks for the quick support and I will keep everyone posted as frequently as I can. I will post results at least once a week. I should also mention that doing anything special around news events would be a major amount of work such as disabling certain pairs when news is released which may affect certain pairs. I will make my best efforts to track major news events and note them in the results I post. If trades opened 3 hours ago and news hits there isn't much you can do about it anyways.  
  
I think once time frames and pairs are selected then managing upcoming news events will be easier. You could choose not to run the EA on certain pairs if news is close to coming out.  
  
Also, I noticed that the S/L is set without considering the spread. If a spread is 5 and you start -5 when the trade opens then you really only have 25 pips breathing room right from the start. Is that the best way or should the spread be considered when setting a S/L? Some ideas off the top of my head for EA mods might be...  
  
Consider the spread. Maybe a setting for max spread allowed? In other words, you could say you don't want to trade unless the spread is less than or equal to say 5 or some other number. IBFX can fluctuate a good deal throughout the day and even the EUR/USD can get a pretty wide spread at times. I think this can have a tendency to hurt EAs because it can get out of hand at times and this would give us more control over choosing our conditions to trade.  
  
Another setting (True/False) for spread to be included in the S/L calculation. That way you can choose to use it or not.  
  
  
I am a programmer so I added a line to show a chart comment showing me the start time and look back hours on the chart. This and maybe some other items shown as chart comments are helpful in saving time so you don't have to check the settings manually. It helps me when running 11 demo accounts each with 19 pairs running. Future updates would be great with this added.  
  
I haven't given the code a great deal of time when looking at it and would like to say that I think it runs well and does what it should. Please don't take my wish list as a dig in any way. I have programmed dozen of EAs myself and know what is involved. My thanks to the programmer responsible for coding it.

Nice one! I'll wait for Mike to correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe this is a mechanical system and as such once the orders are running you can leave them run regardless of news etc, that's what I've been doing. However I know some people like to baby the trades in order to minimise losses/maximise wins.  
  
My feeling is that you could leave all the orders run through news without change - this would mean that all results you obtained should be robust, easily reproduceable and can be used as a worst case baseline.  
  
Many people may feel my views are wrong and please let me know if you have better ideas?  
  
Anyway, thanks again mtab!

I have been testing the system on my demo account for four weeks now on GBP\JPY , EUR\JPY ,USD\JPY and GPP\CHF and results are pretty good . In my short experience I have noticed that most of the times the first target of 15 pips is hit even in losing trades .  
So , I got an idea to adjust trade size as follows :**two** lots with tp 15 pips , **one** lot with tp 30 pips and **one** with tp 50 pips . Of course , it increases risk ,since at worst scenario the loss would be 105 pips instead of 90 , but if the first target is hit ,which happens in most cases , the risk is pretty rewarding .  
What do you think of it ?

I have a question in reguards to this trading idea. I have been looking at this for several days now and love the idea of how this works. As yoy have explained pending orders are placed at HIGH +5 and LOW -5, That means if the market goes up and hits HIGH +5 then we now have three long orders on the pair. If the market turns down then we have three pos at risk with a 30 pip stop loss on each. Here is my idea and I am wondering if anyone has thought of this or tested this. Here it goes..... what if the three orders were placed at HIGH +5, HIGH +7 HIGH +9. Then if the market hits the first one and it is triggered then goes down, the risk is only on one pos and NOT all three. If in fact the market is going to go high enought to make a profit of all three for a total of 95 pips, then we would be giving up a couple pips profit. The way I see it is this might be a saft guard that would save a few losses. What do you think and is it possible to back test this idea against the reg 95 pip plan. I would be currious to see if running a back test against this if it would return more pips threw not losing pos.  
  
I am looking forward to hearing what you guys think about this idea. I am going to begin to test this on my demo account as soon as the market opens.

Hi samoora.  
  
Firstly, my avatar phrase "trading for living" is more of an affirmation of what I'm aspiring for (if that's the reason you're asking).  
I am definitely progressing to the stage of live trading and generating enough income from that to at least get me started with paying the bills.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f644.png?v=15.1)  
  
How much do you need in your trading account to generate your desired income ? Well, firstly that really depends on how much your lifestyle depends upon or how much you would like to earn or how much is really enough...  
Secondly, you have to consider the system you are trading, and equally important, your money management in order to achieve your desired income whilst preserving your trading capital.  
For example, if you are trading a system where the risk:reward is 1:1 you will need to assess how much of your account you are willing to risk on each trade. From what I can gather the standard amongst professional traders is that they will not risk any more than 3% on each trade. So if you had a $10,000 account the max. you would risk on each trade is $300. This would be the amount you would lose if the trade was a loser and also be your profit if the trade is a winner. If you were fortunate enough to achieve an average of 1 winning trade per day you would end up with $1500 over 5 days of trading. Sounds simple doesn't it....but whoa, don't get too excited yet, because the reality can be and often is very different. Just consider if your 1st trade is a loser and your account balance is now $9700. 3% of that is $291. So even if you win the next trade you are still $9 behind. This may seem insignificant but can contribute to your account being eaten away and requiring significantly more winners to recover when you have a string of losing trades.  
So basically the 2 important elements are:  
1\. A winning strategy  
2\. Good money management.   
  
This is a simplistic explanation of how to approach live trading. I cannot emphasise enough the importance of being aware of the downside risk and managing that risk in order to stay in the game.  
  
Regarding the hans system, I do not trade it. There is very little similarity between it and the Daily95pips system.  
  
I hope this helps. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)  
  
rgs  
mike![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)

The results are starting from Sunday afternoon slightly after the market opened. I originally had all the demos running before the market opened on Sunday and when it did open I got all kinds of weird orders being placed most likely due to the time the difference between Friday afternoons time and the starting time on Sunday. So I opened new accounts on each demo to get rid of all the pending orders and started around 6:30pm eastern on Sunday. I notice since using IBFX that a lot of times on Sunday they don't start until 6pm eastern time as well. Doesn't the market open at 5pm on Sundays (eastern time)? Anyways, I am using the IBFX fall EA with all the default which would include UpdateToBE = 15. I have only changed FixedLots to 1, DayStartHour to whatever, and LookBackHours to whatever. When I say whatever I mean based on the spreadsheet above.  
  
If you look at the spreadsheet above you will see that the EUR/GBP has made the most money since Sunday afternoon with $267.34. The darker the green on a particular row the better the profit, the darker the red the worse it has done. The EUR/GBP has done well with a start time of 13 GMT and look back of 13 hours/bars and has done the worst using 00 GMT with a look back of only 2 hours/bars (what I expected). The EUR/GBP has done rather well under most of the situations above but we also need to remember that a pip is worth almost double for the EUR/GBP.  
  
You can also see that $20.46 is the best that the EUR/CAD has done starting at 13 GMT with a look back of 13 hours/bars. The EUR/CAD has not done well under any time setting yet but that may change over time.  
  
I am running 11 demo accounts on all of the 19 pairs listed above. The only thing that varies from one account to the next is the start time and look back hours/bars. All times listed above are GMT and are laid out to overlap using all the different market open times and even looking back almost a whole day as well. I will post the spreadsheet clip above as time goes on so that we can all see which pairs do well under which time settings. Looking back at some of the previous posts I see that some weeks are just a killer and that a majority do well like the post showing ove 2630 pips since August. I am just curious to see if there may be better choices for certain pairs with certain start and look back hours/bars.  
  
Anyways, I am rambling now and I hope I answered your questions and clarified how to read the screen shot above.

Mikelath says he's running a North finance demo and I am running IBFX. I haven't had much luck with IBFX and I'm wondering why I continue to use them. Some of the strangest things have happened with IBFX and I don't believe they're very straight forward. Whenever the news hits their charts freeze for sometimes extended periods (5-10-20 seconds), their [spreads](/brokers/spreads "View Live Spreads on the Broker Guide") fluctuate on a regular basis even when the market is relatively calm, running EAs in demos almost always ends up being different from running live. I have picked a few scenarios from all the demos I am running and made them run on my live account as well (0.01 fixed lots) and the results are not on par with each other.  
  
When I first started trading a few years back I used Intellicharts Desktop and [FXCM](/brokers/fxcm "View FXCM Broker Profile"). I was programming in IntelliScript and using TradeItself as a middle man (program). Intellicharts was programmed to send emails when I needed them and then TradeItself would check that email account and place trades, modify orders, etc. on the FXCM trading platform. That's why I switched to brokers that could use MetaTrader but I miss Intellicharts and the FXCM data stream. Things never froze for me during news, the spreads stayed more consistent, etc. The only problem was FXCM does not use MetaTrader.  
  
I know there is a thread here that discusses brokers but it seems like a lot of opinions and I'm not sure if there are any clear cut winners.  
  
Is there a broker out there that uses MetaTrader that **feels** reliable?  
  
Should I be testing on something other than IBFX?  
  
Is there someone better?  
  
Is IBFX the only broker that closed for Thanksgiving? Is the Forex market closed now as well?

I am trading D95P live, & not with tiny pips either, it is working very well, thank you, Mike Lath.  
I only trade EUR/USD , USD/JPY & the EUR/JPY, they have proven themselves & quite frankly any more pairs are just too hard to handle.  
I trade manually & I place my trades at about 2100 GMT with buy & sell stops. I look back at how my trades progress around the Frankfurt/London open & adjust stops accordingly.  
As the forex market is a 24 hour Market, I don't religously use the previous Days H/L for my calculations, If there was a swing H/L the previous 48 hours, I will Indeed use that, & especially if on the new GMT Day, it is just a continuation of the previous day, I go back to the swing point & use that as my reference & place that in my spreadsheet I gave you all earlier.  
Also, if there is a large spread between the High & the low & the market is near a previous H/L & is close to taking me in, I won't place a trade in the opposite direction if it has to rally 200 or more points to take me in, hence, I trade the breakout in the direction of the trend, & allocate more money as per money management into this trade.  
Also, look at earlier support/resistance, & significant levels, eg, EUR/USD at 1.5000, these whole numbers are VERY important.  
As well I use Fibonnacci levels to aid my trading.  
You just can't blindly trade a "system" you must use your skills as well, after all, the price is always right,  
Bazza

Trading doesn't start for IBFX on Sunday until 6pm EST. The EA reacts strange for me on Sundays opening double pending orders (12 for each pair).  
  
I have changed my strategy for testing as follows:  
  
Demo 1: IBFX 22-17 (19 pairs)  
Demo 2: IBFX 13-17 (19 pairs)  
Demo 3: IBFX 08-17 (19 pairs)  
  
Demo 4: NF 00-17 (19 pairs)  
Demo 5: NF 15-17 (19 pairs)  
Demo 6: NF 10-17 (19 pairs)  
  
22-17 is start hour of 22GMT (5pm EST) looking back 17 hours.  
13-17 is start hour of 13GMT (NY open) looking back 17 hours.  
08-17 is start hour of 08GMT (London open) looking back 17 hours.  
  
00-17 is start hour of 22GMT (5pm EST) looking back 17 hours.  
15-17 is start hour of 13GMT (NY open) looking back 17 hours.  
10-17 is start hour of 08GMT (London open) looking back 17 hours.  
  
North Finance is 2 hours ahead of the IBFX accounts as far as time goes so each are set for 2 hours more than the IBFX demos.  
  
This seems like a good test and I decided to leave everything for 17 hour look backs because that is enough to just slightly overlap a previous market open and is not a full day. My reasoning is to see which pairs do best under which time frames and see if IBFX does better than NF or vice versus.  
  
I restarted my testing because last week was a mess with the holiday and I noticed that NF was running during Thanksgiving? IBFX shut down for a good portion of the day which just messed things up. Also, IBFX doesn't start until 6pm EST whereas my NF demos all started ticking well before 5pm EST. And then there is the issue with IBFX EA opening double orders on Sundays when the market opens. I think it best to start the IBFX demos just after 6pm EST on Sundays and run all week long.  
  
I am also running live on the 3 pairs Mikelath is running on my IBFX account. The situation was the same opening double pending orders on my live account which was scary. I only have $72 left in that account and am trading 0.01 fixed lots. I almost closed it a few weeks back but left a minimal amount just in case. Once I found this thread I was inspired to think I might have a chance again. It will be a good test to see what can happen starting with $72 dollars.

USD/JPY +15 (buy at 108.61)

Hi GridTrader.  
  
To a degree this strategy reduces our risk against the effect of a ranging market by having a relatively small first profit target whereby if achieved the stoploss on the 2 remaining orders is adjusted to breakeven. We do see that price will sometimes trigger the orders and then immediately retrace and stopout all 3 orders for a -90pips result.   
Bear in mind that the EA has a OCO feature that cancels the long orders when the short orders are triggered and visa versa, eliminating the possibility of getting losses on both sides.  
Earlier in the thread there was considerable discussion on the idea of the markets ranging more than trending, thus suggesting the odds being against the success of this strategy. I for one am always open to any positive alternative and a ranging system based on using ATR was touched upon, however not developed sufficiently for greater acceptance. For a while I simultaneously traded a basic ranging strategy along with the D95P system to compare results. There was an idea that one could hedge against the other. My realisation was that not only did the ranging strategy require a lot more development, both strategies tended to cancel out the results of the other. Thus it made more sense to rely on one or the other. Because my focus has been testing the D95P system which relies on a breakout from the previous days high or low I've maintained that focus in order to present clear conclusive results which form the real assessment of it's worth.  
So despite the apparent odds being against this strategy based on it being a trending system rather than a ranging one, ultimately if it's providing good results then all other considerations are rendered less significant.  
  
You're suggestions for improving this system are most welcome.  
  
rgs  
mike![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)

Hi mtaboneweb,  
  
Thanks for setting up a reverse EA. It will be interesting to test out. I notice that you have set it out with orders based at the original third TP point (i.e. 50 pips out).   
  
However if you consider your results the majority of failures occur when the entry orders are triggered and then the spot rate fails to go the 15 pips to the first profit level. So I was wondering if you wouldn't mind setting the reverse system with the sell entry orders at period high +5 (as per Mikes rules) not +50, and the stop at period high +20 ...and the opposite for the buy entry orders below the low for the period chosen.  
  
I was keen for a stop at high +20 since most of the failures come from price action not moving the additional 15 pips to the first profit level (above the high+5 breach point). In this way we can minimise the loss and maximise the gain - since we will have the three profit levels still in place (for the breach of the high +5 pips, these would then be at high-10 pips, high-25 pips, and high-45 pips).  
  
So we are then getting really good risk reward ratios here also. And we could still have the stop to BE when the first pull back level (high -10pips) is reached.  
  
[Spreads](/brokers/spreads "View Live Spreads on the Broker Guide") will have to accomodated also.  
  
Tim

Hi Mike,  
A suggestion for a price filter would be to only allow the EA to set trades for pairs that are less than 1.2x of the previous days ATR(10). With this we would be ensuring that trades were not be set for days that followed very big moves since they are often prone to pullbacks the following day.  
  
Several years ago I worked on a breakout system that took an entry at the open of the new day plus 70% of the previous days ATR(10), and ran a stop of the open-50% of the previous days ATR(10). TP was a time exit which we found best suited to 3 days out from trade entry. (I am not the original system designer).  
  
Results were good, but it would run several months in a row in DD sometimes (so it was best suited to the long term trader). However we found that we could significantly improve the winning trades by including a price filter as I suggest above.  
  
The logic being that breaches on days following a large candle day were much more susceptible to volatile whips as it made the breach of the previous days large range candle.   
  
Maybe this could be considered for future versions of the EA as a possible filter to test?? (Possibly add as a variable to the inputs)  
  
Tim

The IBFX version is the same except for an updated comment that is added to the orders. The comment shown in the attached picture is a mod that I made to the original EA. The example means:  
  
**11/30 \- 0(950017)  
  
Date the order was placed.  
Start hour  
This is the magic number (95 for Daily 95, 00 for start hour, 17 for look back hours)  
  
**I did this to help me sort things out once I save the detailed reports but you have to display the comments in the history tab to see them in the detailed report. If an order is placed on 11/29 then it may not be triggered until 11/30 and the time would also change to when the order actually triggered. It's just my way of preserving the initial information of the order. I also change the magic number for each **account** (not currency) based on the start hour and look back hours. My magic numbers are 950017, 951317, and 952217 to match my settings on each demo account.  
  
The reverse comment would come out looking like this: **11/30 - 0 R (****950017)**  
  
This will help me distinguish the trades further if I ever run a reverse and regular EA on the same account.  
  
The EAs are compiled with their original magic numbers so you will need to change them manually if you would like it to be different. It's one of the settings in the EA properties window. For my demos I loaded my first chart and set everything the way I wanted it (i.e. magic number, fixed lot size, start and look back hours). I then saved it as a template and applied that template to each chart I opened from that point forward for that account. Just a time saving tip.  
  
The magic number needs to be unique for each currency in a single account. That means if you have 2 EUR/USD charts and the same EA attached then each should have a unique magic number like 952217 and 951317 if I were running both time frames on the EUR/USD with 2 charts on the same account. I can have the same magic number if the currencies are different like if I was using the EUR/USD and some other pair(s) on the same account.  
  
When the EA checks to see what it should do it loops through all the orders on your account and looks for those that match the symbol (i.e. EUR/USD) **and** the magic number. I am over explaining for the benefit of anyone who has questions about what the magic number is used for and why it's important to an EA. If anyone has questions or feels that I have confused the issue by over explaining please let me know.  
  
Anyways, long story short, I forgot to add the "R" in the comment when I compiled it for the original post. If you have to have the "R" then you will want the version from the most recent post.

As we look at the ongoing and daily results we need to remember that each time frame should come close to matching each other. You can see the 08-17 time frame differs a lot between brokers (IBFX -2485 / NF -1920). Look at the AUD/USD as an example (IBFX -85 / NF +155). That's a big difference but in the 13-17 time frame the EUR/CHF did better on IBFX.  
  
This week is difficult to make any quick judgments. Normally the 3 pairs do well but not this week so far. The GBP/CHF has done well this week but may not on a week when the other 3 pairs are doing better. Also, the EUR/CHF has done very good in the 13-17 time frame although better on the IBFX demo.  
  
I can't really say why the demos are so different. I'm not sure if it could be lag due to running so many pairs on so many demos all at once on my computer or something else. Highs and lows will vary from one broker to another and that could be part of it. The extra lag that I've noticed with the NF demos may actually play a part in those demos doing slightly better and yet I feel that lag is not a good thing in trading. Where it might have played a beneficial part this week may not be the case next week. The IBFX 22-17 was the only one that had higher numbers overall.  
  
We should really start to pick these charts apart and see what sense we can make of it. As the weeks pass the picture will hopefully become clearer. I do feel a single week is too short a time to make any decisions.  
  
As for next week I am unsure what to do. Do I stop the NF demos and run the reverse demos on the 3 time frames on IBFX demos? Do I continue as is to get a clearer picture not only between time frames but brokers as well? Could there be a problem running so much at once on a single computer?  
  
I do believe we should start testing the reverse because all of the negatives above could have been potential positives and that is encouraging. I wonder how the reverse will do on a week that supports break outs on the original 3 pairs. Are certain pairs more likely to break out rather than rebound?  
  
Any thoughts?

Hiya Bob.  
  
My understanding is that your computer must be turned on for the duration within the week that you would like the EA to function for. From what I can gather, the EA is attached to and functions from your computer, not the broker.You would therefore need to have the hibernate option switched turned off in the screensaver section of the control panel. The reason for this is twofold:  
1\. To ensure that the computer is on when the EA is due to calculate the new orders for the day.  
2\. To ensure that the computer is on to manage any open trades ie. executing profit targets and stops.  
  
As for whether you need the trading platform to be constantly open for the EA to still work, I'm not 100% sure. Personally, I keep the trading platform open for the whole week (Sunday night to Saturday morning Brisbane time)and minimise it while I do other stuff on the computer.   
  
If you are running the NF fall version the default settings are set to the 'standard' rules of the D95P strategy as per post#1. If you are happy with these settings then you don't need to change a thing. Pr1mer has programmed the EA to calculate order sizes based on a % of the account balance, thus achieving the desired money management objective. He has included a word doc with instructions outlining each setting ( sorry, I can't remember which post it's at ). The only difference between Pr1mer's latest version of the EA and PipHunter's fall EA's is that piphunter has adjusted the DayStartHour to suit numerous brokers who start the day at different times, thus making it easier for newbies unfamiliar with how to adjust the input settings on the EA. I'm immensely grateful to both of them.  
  
rgs

The platform needs to be running as long as there are open orders or pending orders. The EA has to be active to manage the trades as the charts tick. It's what is responsible for moving the stop loss to break even after +15 is achieved, trailing stops if chosen, etc. It also closes the opposite trades. The system would not produce good results without this maintenance of the orders.

Hi everybody - as always - thanks for the input and the hard work - you know who you are...  
  
**I am wondering if anybody has tried starting their orders, whether live or not, at the open of Tokyo market?** **If so, what have been the results?** In my IBFX live account (using teeny, tiny lots) there seems to be a lot of price volatility when the volumes are thin. This would seem to lead to more - saying this nicely - market manipulation.  
  
I don't know if the thin volumes are working for us or against us.   
  
**2nd item - With the reversing - here is another thought**. Again, on days where we have had a big move in the market and the close is near the top or the bottom of that big move, the market always have a tendency to do some retracing. We have the problem of orders getting triggered and then stopped out with this retracing. I believe this is being addressed with the reverse changes made in the EA.   
  
The second piece of this puzzle is the fact that the opposite order is set way on the other side of this big move. For example, let's say a pair moves 200 pips up in a given day. Before our sell orders are triggered, the market would have to retrace the entire 200 pips plus 5 more (or whatever number you are using) before our sells would be triggered. Way into this 200+ pip move, the tide has obviously turned.   
I have seen in several different places, the use of a calculation to determine when the market momentum has reverse. The term used I have seen most is '**pivot point** '. The calculation of the pivot point is easy enough:  
  
(Previous Period Close + Previous Period High + Previous Period Low) / 3  
  
Most of you are far more experienced and smarter than I am, **do you think a pivot point +or- 5 pips on the day after a big move might yield more pips?  
  
**Comments and input please....  
  
  
Tim

I reset the accounts on Sunday afternoon so there will be no trades for the 22-17 time frame for IBFX or NF. Both placed trades improperly opening pending orders times 2, 3, 4, and even more on some currencies. Somewhere in the roll over from Friday to Sunday the EA gets confused. It most likely has something to do with when the time stops ticking on Friday and when it starts back on Sunday. Even if I start the demos shortly after the market open on Sunday it initially places double, triple, etc. orders which I would have to manually close to get things evened out. The 1st solution I can think of is to disable experts on the whole account before the market opens on Sunday and then re-enable them after the time gets itself worked out. This is a temporary fix for now and it requires that you are in front of your computer on Sunday at market open. Maybe our original programmers could take a look at the code? Everything about this EA seems to be great except for this one Sunday bug.

I only trade one pair using this system, and that is EUR/USD. I do not however blindly use this system every day, but instead use discretion, and have had pretty good luck with it. I chose not to trade short today based on price being on the trend line. Yes, that trend line may be broken, but until it is, I decided not to trade, and saved myself 90 pips. When it's trending up, like it has been for years now, I only take long trades. Granted, we may be in for a bigger correction, and I may take short trades again, once the trend line is broken, and price is back in the bigger channel. I know in some cases, my discretion will be wrong, but it's just my personallity not to let an EA do "all" the trading for me :-)

Some of the issues I've had with this EA are below:  
  
1\. If the pending orders have been placed and you close and re-open MetaTrader while it's still within the hour to place the pending orders, then it places another set of pending orders. The EA doesn't do a good job of checking to see if pending orders have already been placed. The EA needs to check things out before it opens pending orders.  
  
2\. If you have double pending orders for a currency and one direction is triggered only 3 of the opposite trades are canceled leaving 3 others that could be triggered later in the opposite direction. Double orders shouldn't happen in the first place but the EA should still be able to handle this situation.  
  
3\. If it turns out that moving the SL to BE is a lag issue where the broker somehow turns the order to modify down then the EA should re-try on the next tick of the chart until it can be set.  
  
I also think that there should be an option in the EA to say true/false for directly opening orders if the currency is too close to the high/low to place pending orders. In this case it would place direct trades in that direction and not even bother setting pending orders in the opposite direction. Suggestions have been made to place x amount of pips even higher or lower but I feel if you're going to set it that close in the first place then you might as well get in sooner and have a better chance at your TP. If you set it 5 above or below then you will most likely hit that anyways and you've already lost an additional 5 pips already in that direction.  
  
Another idea... Has anyone considered setting the +50 TP's stop loss to +15 once the +30 TP order has hit. In this case if you hit +15 and +30 and your +50 never happens then you would still have +15 for a total of +60 if it only went as far as the +30 marker instead of falling all the way back to 0 leaving you with +45 instead. I realize that moving a SL up would possibly decrease the possibility that the +50 might have enough room to hit +50 but it does ensure more of a profit if it never makes it all the way. I would rather take +15 more on the last order rather than wait for +50 which may not happen. This may leave to small of a window for the maximum profit. It could be added as a true/false setting in the EA.  
  
Thoughts?

The magic number is not the issue as long as they are different pairs. The EA looks for a match of the magic number **and** the symbol for the chart it's running on.  
  
Under the options menu there is an Expert Advisor tab. The 2nd and 3rd checkboxes from the top are what I'm talking about. Allow live trading does **not** need to be checked here as long as it **is** checked on the EA's settings on the chart.

> [Quoting mtaboneweb](/thread/post/1748004#post1748004 "View Quoted Post")
> 
> Disliked
> 
> Some of the issues I've had with this EA are below:  
>    
>  1\. If the pending orders have been placed and you close and re-open MetaTrader while it's still within the hour to place the pending orders, then it places another set of pending orders. The EA doesn't do a good job of checking to see if pending orders have already been placed. The EA needs to check things out before it opens pending orders.  
>    
>  2\. If you have double pending orders for a currency and one direction is triggered only 3 of the opposite trades are canceled leaving 3 others that could be triggered later in the opposite direction. Double orders shouldn't happen in the first place but the EA should still be able to handle this situation.  
>    
>  3\. If it turns out that moving the SL to BE is a lag issue where the broker somehow turns the order to modify down then the EA should re-try on the next tick of the chart until it can be set.  
>    
>  I also think that there should be an option in the EA to say true/false for directly opening orders if the currency is too close to the high/low to place pending orders. In this case it would place direct trades in that direction and not even bother setting pending orders in the opposite direction. Suggestions have been made to place x amount of pips even higher or lower but I feel if you're going to set it that close in the first place then you might as well get in sooner and have a better chance at your TP. If you set it 5 above or below then you will most likely hit that anyways and you've already lost an additional 5 pips already in that direction.  
>    
>  Another idea... Has anyone considered setting the +50 TP's stop loss to +15 once the +30 TP order has hit. In this case if you hit +15 and +30 and your +50 never happens then you would still have +15 for a total of +60 if it only went as far as the +30 marker instead of falling all the way back to 0 leaving you with +45 instead. I realize that moving a SL up would possibly decrease the possibility that the +50 might have enough room to hit +50 but it does ensure more of a profit if it never makes it all the way. I would rather take +15 more on the last order rather than wait for +50 which may not happen. This may leave to small of a window for the maximum profit. It could be added as a true/false setting in the EA.  
>    
>  Thoughts?
> 
> Ignored

  
  
These are all excellent ideas. I specifically agree with the Take Profit settings idea. This week alone, I had two trades on my FXDD platform which were +15, 0, 0. I would rather have the profit than not. Especially since we may be getting into the holiday doldrums soon.   
  
Any chance we could take a vote? :-)  
  
Sam

Hi leo9 and welcome to the D95P thread.  
  
Yes, the strategy uses the high and low of the previous 17hrs from 5pm EST (which is 17:00 by 24hr time). So we are using the high and low of practically the whole day(17hrs), not for that hour only. Monday is the exception as weekend activity is often minimal, therefore we use the data going back to midnight Friday morning.  
I suggest that you simply use the Expert Advisor to automate the trading of this strategy. If EA's are new to you then just ask for assistance and we'll guide you from there.

Hi All  
  
Firstly a big thanks to mikelath for sharing this system and results and thanks to all other regular contributors for helping it develop.  
  
I have been following the thread for some time now and testing manually for the last 2 weeks. I am using the GFT broker at the moment so cannot use any of the posted ea's.   
  
I am in the GMT timezone and I have been placing my orders at 8am gmt with a 24hr look back. I think the 24hr lookback is important as I want to include moves from the start of yesterdays London session as part of my daily range.   
Apart from that the strategy is as per page 1 of the thread. I have been moving the stop loss of the 3rd (50 pip target) trade to breakeven when the 2nd target is hit.  
  
I have only been using 2 pairs with results (for 9 days) as follows:-  
GBP/USD = +105  
EUR/JPY = +330  
  
I can post the spreadsheet if required.

I am currently reading Kathy Lien's book titled 'Day trading the currency market' within which there is chapter titled 'best time to trade for individual currency pairs. You can find this chapter here:-

I think it's good for people to experiment with different ideas on this strategy. That's exactly what I'm doing. At this point I am just keeping it simple and close to the original idea that started this thread. I would also like to say that I believe **back testing** has proven to be flawed more often than it has been correct. I would not discourage anyone from running a back test and sharing but I would also ask that people don't jump ship just because someone got bad results in a back test. I am of the thinking that the only good way to test is with forward live testing. Even under a great model quality in back testing is never more than 90% and live testing almost always proves to differ from back testing.

Here is my setup with the fall EA for IBFX and NF...  
  
08-17 (London open)

IBFX demo, 18 pairs, start hour set to 8 (Column B)  
NF demo, 18 pairs, start hour set to 10 (8 GMT Column D)  

13-17 (New York open)

IBFX demo, 18 pairs, start hour set to 13 (Column F)  
NF demo, 18 pairs, start hour set to 15 (13 GMT Column H)  

22-17 (Original strategy)

IBFX demo, 18 pairs, start hour set to 22 (Column J)  
NF demo, 18 pairs, start hour set to 0 (22 GMT Column L)  

The NF time is 2 hours greater than IBFX which is GMT time. That's why the NF demos get set 2 hours greater.  
  
Six demos testing 3 different start hours to compare which pair does good under which start time and then which broker did better than the other.  
  
My results so far have been mixed showing certain pairs performing better with certain brokers. Notice how the AUD/JPY produced 330 pips (9 days with an average of 37 pips) on the IBFX demo. This pair did better than the North Finance demo under the same settings. This could be due to lag, data stream, etc.  
  
I have highlighted a few areas to point out some major differences that caught my eye. Se the magenta highlighted area? IBFX had 7 days it was triggered where the NF only triggered on 4 days. This was due to the NF demo being too close to even set the pending orders so they were never made. It show some differences between brokers because the IBFX demo had less problems setting the pending orders and then triggering them.  
  
I use these results to pick out settings for certain pairs and possibly even certain brokers.  
  
Are these results a benefit to anyone or should I keep it to myself? I don't seem to get a lot of feedback from anyone looking at them except with questions about what they show. I don't want to waste anyones time or create excessive posts when no one may be interested.

If you are running an IBFX demo or real account then the time in the software is GMT time in which case you would set start time to 8 if you wanted 8 GMT. Your own time zone should not affect the time shown in the MetaTrader software. If you are going manual then you'll have to do some work to figure the difference between your time and GMT. Since I run IBFX and North Finance demos they are different. IBFX is GMT so I would set it at 8 in the EA settings. NF is 2 hours ahead so I set that for 10 in the EA settings. The point is you want it to be based on GMT 0 not + or - anything.

  * | Joined Nov 2007  | Status: Commercial Member | [694 Posts](/search?do=process&provider=Member&searchuser=53951)

It needs to be running period. It wont place pending orders or do maintenance to existing orders if it's not running with the EA attached to the chart and the EA enabled. An EA _cannot_ work unless the software is running. I'm only stressing this because people seem to ask this question a lot. Each time the chart is updated (tick) it fires the EA which applies the logic within itself and does any needed actions. If it's not running then it can't do anything and you most certainly don't want to turn off the software after pending orders are placed. The orders will become active when the price is reached but without the EA running it wont cancel the opposite orders, adjust stop losses once pips is hit on the first order, trail stops if selected, etc.

  * [#1,327](/thread/post/1761763#post1761763 "Post Permalink")

  * Dec 17, 2007 1:41am  Dec 17, 2007 1:41am 

  * [![](https://assets.faireconomy.media/nfs/customavatars/thumbs/medium/avatar53951_5.gif) mtaboneweb](mtaboneweb)

  * | Joined Nov 2007  | Status: Commercial Member | [694 Posts](/search?do=process&provider=Member&searchuser=53951)

You have to leave it running. It is set and forget because the **EA** does all the work for you. The EA is not only responsible for setting the pending orders but many other things as well...  
  
Once a set of pending orders are triggered the EA closes the opposite orders. If the buys are triggered then it closes the pending sells or vice versa.  
  
Once the first 15 pips is achieved and that order closes at it's take profit then the EA moves the other 2 orders to break even on their stop loss.  
  
If you have trailing stop enabled then the EA manages resetting the stop loss as the last trade moves.  
  
All of these things would have to be done manually if it weren't for the MetaTrader platform and the custom EA that has been written to manage all of this for us. Each time a chart is updated (tick) then the EA runs it's logic and does what is supposed to happen if anything at all at that point. If the software isn't running and the chart isn't open and the EA isn't attached then the system cant to anything with the orders it placed. Dozens of people ask this same question on nearly every thread here. **If you set your alarm clock and then unplug it will it go off when it's supposed to? An alarm clock ticks throughout the day each time determining if it need to sound the alarm every second that passes. It will not do it's thing if it's not powered on and EAs are the same way.** The broker does not do the work for you and when you set something like this up the logic behind the EA is not stored someplace magically and continues to run for you even after you close the software. It requires that everything be in place and running, period.

For mike:  
This is one of the most valuable system i have tested.  
  
For everyone in this thread:  
I have concluded that the system would work more accurate if price is not ranging on larger TF's, hence we have to look at the higher timeframes to make sure that we are in a correct trend.   
Always remember that this system only works on trends, NOT SIDEWAYS, because in a sideway condition, price always bounce at support and resistance, before a breakout.  
Consequently, always beware when currencies are on sideways on the higher timeframes. To help this, always draw trend lines for the higher TF's.
